lines.text: [last lines]
What if your real granddaughter comes back?
Perhaps she has.
So, after you left, we examined the fireplace. There was a loose stone...
You're kiddin'?
And there was something hidden in the canopy behind it.
[takes out a small, shiny box from behind her back]
Do you recognize this?
No.
Look closer, dear. Are you sure you've never seen it? It's very important!
No. No. Although...
[begins to whistle the first notes of a tune, then opens the box, which turns out to be a music box that completes the melody]
Uh, I don't understand...
Oh, my dear. Oh, my dear!... Welcome to Candleshoe!
[embraces Casey, crying]
Don't lose your garlic.
You can peel and core the apples Queenie. I'm busy.

[Casey has told everyone at Candleshoe the real reason for her arrival and what she has discovered thus far. They are all at the graveyard looking at the headstone]
... And this was the last clue. He followed the Eclipse for riches and fame...
And if ye would prosper, do ye the same. What does it mean?

Why, it's very simple. The Eclipse was a ship. Captain Joshua's ship. There's a picture of it in the house, of Captain Joshua accepting the surrender of a Spanish vessel on the Spanish main. Dear Lord, well, that's the clue! Come on everyone! It's hanging in the hall!
Um, my Lady!

[remembers]
It's not hanging in the hall...

[Lady St. Edmund has called an emergency meeting with Mr. Thresher]
You sold it, Mr. Thresher, you sold my painting?
Well, my lady, it was my painting. You sold to me, that is, well, Mr. Priory sold it to me, that is...
Mr. Thresher, we certaintly have no quams with the sale, but we must get a look at it. So if you would, please tell us who you sold it to,and where is it now?
Ah, I sold it to an elderly woman only yesterday. She said, that Captain Joshua reminded her of her father...
Another pirate, no doubt.
20 for London!
20. Thank you Mr. Thresher. Come along, everyone. We must get to the station!
15 now!
That train never leaves on time, if we hurry we should just make it.

[Jenkins has caught Casey as she is trying to flee the apartment]
Let go of me! I'm a minor!
[held by the arm, Casey is flung back into the apartment]
You creeps! You lousy creeps! Sold me out to the cops, huh?
Shut up!
[to Jenkins]
Well, this is her!

[Casey is again grabbed by Jenkins, who examines her shoulderblade and forehead, looking at the scars. Satisfied that Casey is the one he is looking for, he tosses a large envelope of money on the table. Mr. McCress greedily opens the envelope and begins counting]

[hands a suitcase to Jenkins]
Here's the rest of her stuff.
Mind the axe, my lady.
I don't suppose your experience with family life has been a happy one.

What family life? Tell ya, the only thing i remember about family life is nothing. Zero. One foster dump to another. I mean who really cares about a kid you take in just for the welfare money and the food stamps? I mean who really cares? It's a racket, just like anything else. The whole world's a racket. First thing i ever learned. you get up out of bed in the morning with your dukes up. You got 'em up, first punch is yours.
I see.
Yeah, well, maybe you do and maybe you don't.
But you can't go through life alone.
I ain't alone. I got me. Listen, if you don't hand it out you don't have to worry about not getting it back.
I'm not deprived; I'm delinquent. There's a difference, you know.

[far too posh]
Teddy and Piggywig!
For the sunrise student, there is treasure among books.
The paths of glory lead but to the grave. That's it! I found the clue.

[reading headstone]
He followed the eclipse for riches and fame and if ye would prosper do ye the same.
You swag! My regimental tie.
They're nice and squishy.
Priory!
My Lady?
Gagh!
[puts down the spoon]
Eat it!
I can't! I've had enough! Uh...
[looks for a place to dump the rice pudding out]
Strawberries, shortbread, rice pudding? I must say, that was very unscrupulous of you, Priory.
Quite right, My Lady. Most unscrupulous.
We'll just let things take their course, shall we, Priory?

[bows]
Very good.

[re-telling the story of Casey's homecoming to Grismworthy]
Welcome to Candleshoe!
[hugs Clara]
Welcome to Candleshoe!
She did it?
She bloody did! It would be wonderful for Mr. Bundage, to go to town, be the life of the party!
[roughly packs the rest of Casey's things in a suitcase]
Well, whose to say we couldn't own the town?
Oh, Harry! Harry!
Clara. We are in. We are in!
Oh ho ho ho ho! Ha Ha, La La La La! Oh ho!
[her and Harry begin to dance with glee]

[rushes into the lake to break up the fight between Anna, Casey and Cluny]
Are you all right?
Yeah. Yeah, I'm OK... I'm fine!
[holds her eye and trods out of the lake]

[holds Cluny and Anna each by the arm]
You two ought to be ashamed of yourselves! Two against one!

[on the shore]
Yes! And what will Grandmother say when she finds out?

[stands in front of the mirror after she has showered. She wipes the fog off the glass. The bathroom door behind her opens and Jenkins and Bundage walk in]
Don't nobody knock around this place?
[both men stare at Casey]
Who's this joker?
[walks up to Casey, roughly looks at her scars on her forehead and shoulderblade]
The markings are just the way you described them!
Yes!
[turns back to Casey]
Where did you get those scars?

[sarcastically]
Rudolph Valentino beat me 'cuz I wouldn't marry 'em!

[slaps Casey across the face]
That's the last time you sass me! Now! Where did those scars come from?
I don't remember.
[Harry raises his hand to slap Casey again, Casey flinches]
Just keep on, not remembering!
[throws a box on the table next to the sink]
Put those on!
[turns to Jenkins]
Excellent work, Mr. Jenkins! I'm very pleased!
Good, good! Will there be anything else, Mr. Bundage?
No, no.

[has opened the box and holds up the garment]
A dress?
Put it on.

[Lady St. Edmund and Casey have gone into the garden to look for the gardener, Mr. Gidding]
Gidding? Gidding?
[see the gardener bent over a rose bush, trimming it]
Mr. Gidding! I would have a word with you. I thought I made it quite clear that there were to be fresh roses on the landing every morning!

[disguised as Mr. Gidding, the gardener]
Your orders? I don't give a hoot en hoot about your orders, the roses come first!
Oh, do they indeed? You know, you used to be a good, pleasant gardener. But in recent years, you have become fairly tiresome and crotchety!
Oh, that's the way, is it? Crotchety, am I? If I known we going to thoroughly examine my character, I would have washed my hands and put on my Sunday best!
Gidding! We are discussing the roses!
Now, that's enough of that! You two go off and toodle over the property and I'll take care of what I do best!
Mr. Gidding!
Here here! Now see here, I'll trim my roses as I see fit!
Your roses? Very well. If that is your attitude, you are dismissed!
[nods for effect, and her and Casey walk away]
Priory? Priory!

[rushes back into the house through the back entrance. The kids are there waiting]
Quick, help!
[the children help Priory to get out of his disguise and back into his butler uniform]
Get the boots, get the boots!

[Priory has his butler uniform back on and is about to answer Lady St. Edmund]
Psst! Psst!
[Priory looks back, Peter points to his eyebrows and mouths the word Eyebrows, meaning Priory still has the fake ones on]

[Priory quickly takes them off and stuffs them in his pocket, then puts the stale bread bag on the tray he is carrying]
Yes, My Lady?

[breathing heavily]
Oh Priory! I have dismissed Gidding. I wish him packed and out of here by this evening!
I see. Do you think that decision might have been a little rash, My Lady?
Certaintly not! He was impertanant!
Oh, that's just his way, My Lady. And may I say, he would be very hard, for me to replace.
He would?
Very hard. And I would ensure that he had fresh roses on the landing, every morning.
You would? Well, I suppose I, might give him one more chance. But you may tell him, that this is positively his last!
Yes, My Lady. Oh, My Lady, the stale bread.
[hands Lady St. Edmund the bag]
Oh, thank you, Priory.

[Casey has just come out of the closet after talking privately with Bundage]
Who were you telephoning?
My stock broker. I told him to order 100 pounds of Alakazam Salt and Pepper.
Listen, you're up to something.
[steps closer]
I want to know what it is.
Na, you listen. If you don't keep your snout out of my business,
[squints and smiles]
your smeller will wind up where your ears 'otta be.
It's engaged!
What?
Busy!
Please play the gramophone record, Priory, and you and I will waltz.
Oh no, my lady, absolutely not.
I insist.
Oh no, my lady, it wouldn't be appropriate.
Would it be appropriate if I were to dance with Col. Dennis? I'm sure he dances better than he rides.
[pause]
You did him very well Priory.
You knew?
We were playing games with time, you and I. And I thank you for it.
My lady, I'm terribly embarrassed.
You needn't be. I'm very grateful. For your splendid talent, and even more for your compasssion. And now if you please, the gramophone record.
You're a hustler.
A what?
A hustler. A con man. I can smell 'em a mile away.
You take care your smeller don't end up where your ears oughta be!
Maybe that's the clue, Harry, when he died! Maybe that means something.
Like what? He didn't know when he was gonna die!

[Knock on the door]
Yeah, who is it? Come on in.
It's me. You awake?
Yeah, I think I am. How come you're not in bed?
I've got something for you.
What's that?
Garlic.
Garlic?
Garlic. Keeps ghosts away.
Garlic keeps everyone away.
Now Cluny you've already met.
Yeah, right, I met Cluny.
Over here, struggling with the churn, is Peter.
Hi.
Hello, welcome to Candleshoe.
This is Anna.

[From above]
Hey, somebody catch!
[He tosses a jar. Casey catches it]
Hey, well held!

[Bobby slides down the column into the kitchen]
The acrobatic member of the family is Bobby.
Grandmother, now that your real granddaughter is here, does it mean that we'll be sent away?
Good gracious! If I did that, whom would I find to slide up and down the great hall?
[She kisses the top of his head. He smiles, then takes a running slide down the Great Hall]
Splendid!
I don't mind in the least that you lied to me when you first came to Candleshoe. But I would be very hurt if you lied to me now. Do you really want to go back to Los Angeles?

[Casey begins to cry and is embarassed]
I've never cried in my life.
Then I think it's time that you did. Come on, my dear. We're going home.
[they leave the train station together]
